summary: The document provides a detailed briefing on Robert Morton Geddes, a British subject with activities in Cuba during the early 1960s, including his interactions with the CIA, arrest in Havana, and the suspicions of espionage or being a provocateur. It outlines a chronology of his activities and communications, alongside the inquiries and tensions between British and American intelligence regarding his case.
key_findings: Robert Morton Geddes was a British subject born in Peru, involved in activities that raised suspicions of espionage or being a provocateur.
Geddes was arrested in Havana and interrogated, during which he denied being a CIA agent but was shown a message allegedly sent by him requesting CIA aid to Cuba.
The British Embassy in Havana had concerns about Geddes possibly being a British agent, but this was not confirmed.
A detailed chronology of Geddes' activities from March to April 1961 is provided, highlighting his movements and communications.
The document reveals tensions and questions between British and American intelligence regarding Geddes' true allegiances and activities.
